Literature Review: Metastasis, the spread of cancer cells from the primary tumor to distant organs, is the leading cause of cancer-related deaths. Traditionally, metastasis was thought to occur through the dissemination of individual tumor cells. However, recent evidence has highlighted the significance of collective migration and metastasis by tumor cell clusters, challenging this long-held paradigm.Collective migration, a process where cells move as cohesive groups while maintaining cell-cell contacts, has been observed in various biological contexts, including embryonic development and wound healing. In cancer, this phenomenon has gained increasing attention due to its potential role in metastasis. Acini et al. (2015) demonstrated that tumor cell clusters could detach from primary tumors and enter the bloodstream as multicellular units, termed circulating tumor cell clusters (CTCs).The advantages of collective migration in cancer metastasis are multifaceted. Cheung et al. (2016) showed that tumor cell clusters have a higher metastatic potential compared to single cells, with up to 50-fold increased metastatic efficiency. This enhanced metastatic ability is attributed to several factors. Firstly, cell-cell adhesion within clusters provides survival signals that protect against anoikis, a form of programmed cell death triggered by detachment from the extracellular matrix. Gkountela et al. (2019) identified that clusters upregulate cell-cell junction components, particularly plakoglobin, which contributes to their survival advantage.Moreover, collective migration allows for the maintenance of tumor heterogeneity during metastasis. Maddipati and Stanger (2015) used lineage tracing in a mouse model of pancreatic cancer to demonstrate that metastases can arise from polyclonal seeding events, where multiple subclones from the primary tumor co-metastasize as a cluster. This polyclonal nature of metastases may contribute to their increased adaptability and resistance to therapy.The immune evasion capabilities of tumor cell clusters further enhance their metastatic potential. Szczerba et al. (2019) found that CTCs can associate with neutrophils, forming clusters that shield tumor cells from immune attack and promote their survival in circulation. Additionally, these neutrophil-CTC clusters showed increased metastatic potential compared to CTC clusters alone.Despite these advantages, tumor cell clusters face unique challenges during metastasis, particularly during intravasation and extravasation. Their larger size compared to single cells poses physical constraints for entering and exiting blood vessels. However, recent studies have shed light on how clusters overcome these obstacles. Chung et al. (2017) observed that clusters can reshape into single-file chains to traverse narrow capillaries, demonstrating their remarkable plasticity.The molecular mechanisms underlying collective migration and metastasis are gradually being elucidated. Labernadie et al. (2017) identified a heterophilic adhesion system between E-cadherin on cancer cells and N-cadherin on stromal fibroblasts, which facilitates collective invasion. This finding highlights the importance of tumor-stroma interactions in collective migration.Intracellular signaling pathways also play crucial roles in orchestrating collective behavior. Yasuda et al. (2018) demonstrated that the YAP/TAZ pathway, known for its role in mechanotransduction, is essential for collective migration in breast cancer. Inhibition of this pathway disrupted collective behavior and reduced metastatic potential.To study collective metastasis, researchers have developed various models. Organoid cultures, as described by Broutier et al. (2017), provide a three-dimensional system that better recapitulates the complexity of tumor architecture compared to traditional 2D cultures. Additionally, intravital imaging techniques have allowed for real-time visualization of collective migration in vivo, as demonstrated by Kedrin et al. (2008).The growing understanding of collective metastasis opens new avenues for therapeutic interventions. Targeting cell-cell adhesion molecules or pathways specific to collective behavior could potentially disrupt metastatic spread. Furthermore, the identification of circulating tumor cell clusters as highly potent metastatic precursors suggests their potential use as prognostic biomarkers.In conclusion, the orchestration of collective migration and metastasis by tumor cell clusters represents a paradigm shift in our understanding of cancer progression. This collective behavior confers several advantages, including enhanced survival, maintenance of tumor heterogeneity, and immune evasion. As research in this field progresses, it promises to yield new insights into the metastatic process and potentially lead to novel strategies for preventing and treating metastatic disease.
